sentences.sentence: By Jairo YunisFor decades we've seen Canadian governments of all stripes compete in the "Subsidy Olympics."
Like athletes chasing after medals, governments vie to see who can give out the largest, broadest, and most expensive subsidies(https://financialpost.com/tag/subsidies/) to large corporations.

This race to own the subsidy podium has resulted in billions of taxpayer dollars being handed to large firms in oil and gas, auto manufacturing, green energy, aerospace, food retail, technology and other industries.The recent $13-billion subsidy to Volkswagen(https://financialpost.com/commodities/energy/electric-vehicles/canada-investment-roi-volkswagen-battery-plant) and fresh top-up of the Stellantis subsidy(https://financialpost.com/commodities/energy/electric-vehicles/ontario-boosts-stellantis-subsidy-windsor-battery-plant) only add to a long list that includes Loblaws, Bombardier, BlackBerry, Suncor, Canada Goose and many more.

A recent Fraser Institute study(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/sites/default/files/cost-of-business-subsidies-in-canada.pdf) revealed that between 2007 and 2019, Canadian governments at all levels spent a whopping (and inflation-adjusted) $352.1 billion in financial aid to businesses, with the federal government alone offering $76.7 billion in subsidies.However well-intentioned, the reality of corporate subsidies is that they often lead to significant unintended consequences for the economy, particularly for small businesses(https://financialpost.com/category/entrepreneur/small-business/).

While subsidies are often seen as a quick fix to stimulate growth and create jobs, they ultimately create an uneven playing-field, discourage innovation and burden taxpayers.Why should governments get to pick winners and losers or decide which industries get a position on the subsidy podium?
Doing so artificially skews market competition in favour of the subsidized firms.

This gives larger corporations unfair advantages: they can afford to navigate the bureaucratic process required to obtain subsidies by hiring armies of lawyers and accountants and battalions of grant writers.
Small businesses, often at the forefront of innovation, are particularly disadvantaged as they struggle to compete with subsidized giants.

As a result, innovation and efficiency take a backseat, harming our overall economic health.By messing with market dynamics, subsidies create an environment in which businesses succeed based on their ability to secure public funding, not meet consumer demand in an open and competitive market.
That's not entrepreneurship.
It's "grant-repreneurship.
"Let's be honest: subsidies are rarely temporary measures.
Once established, they tend to become deeply ingrained and difficult to eliminate.

This perpetuates a cycle of dependency, where industries grow reliant on continued taxpayer support and become populated by "zombie firms" that only survive with government assistance.Governments arbitrarily choosing which businesses thrive and which fail is not a sound economic policy, and will cause long-term damage to Canada's growth, productivity and small-business competitiveness.It's important to acknowledge that small businesses faced unprecedented challenges during the pandemic, with public health restrictions, tight credit conditions, and lockdowns impeding their ability to operate.
Governments stepped in and provided, not traditional individual subsidies, but time-limited and broadly available support to help these businesses navigate this uncharted passage.
In fact, small businesses are eager to pay back their emergency loans and escape the debt burden they've had to assume.

An extension of the repayment deadline would be helpful to many as they strive to recover from three very challenging years.Quebec's new honour system for French won't last 3 weeks(https://financialpost.com/opinion/quebec-new-honour-system-french-wont-last-3-weeks)Ontario's Doug Ford out-NDPs the NDP on auto subsidies(https://financialpost.com/opinion/ontario-doug-ford-out-ndps-ndp-auto-subsidies)Give property rights to First Nations individuals to kill colonialism(https://financialpost.com/opinion/give-property-rights-first-nations-kill-colonialism)But while this support was necessary during the once-in-a-century circumstance, it is not a sustainable solution for long-term economic growth.

With economies open again, the COVID subsidy taps have been closed, and rightly so.To truly support small businesses and foster long-term economic growth, we should urge governments to shift away from a subsidy-driven approach and explore policies that promote fair competition, foster innovation, and empower entrepreneurs to thrive.

Only by reducing the cost of doing business, modernizing rules and regulations and focusing on supply-side policies can we create an economy where small businesses have a fair chance to succeed and contribute to the prosperity of all Canadians.
Ask any small business owner what they really want, and they'll tell you: just a chance to compete.Jairo Yunis is the Canadian Federation of Independent Business' economist for Western Canada.
@COPYRIGHT=© 2023 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is moderately confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

Like athletes chasing after medals, governments vie to see who can give out the largest, broadest, and most expensive subsidies(https://financialpost.com/tag/subsidies/) to large corporations. This race to own the subsidy podium has resulted in billions of taxpayer dollars being handed to large firms in oil and gas, auto manufacturing, green energy, aerospace, food retail, technology and other industries.The recent $13-billion subsidy to Volkswagen(https://financialpost.com/commodities/energy/electric-vehicles/canada-investment-roi-volkswagen-battery-plant) and fresh top-up of the Stellantis subsidy(https://financialpost.com/commodities/energy/electric-vehicles/ontario-boosts-stellantis-subsidy-windsor-battery-plant) only add to a long list that includes Loblaws, Bombardier, BlackBerry, Suncor, Canada Goose and many more.
